title: Current to plate with Ag or Au

content.question: Half-Reaction Standard Reduction Potential, <math alttext="E naught in volts" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></math> <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge aqueous plus one electron produce A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Ag(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="positive 0.80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="A u with a positive 3 charge aqueous plus 3 electrons produce A u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Au(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="positive 1.50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Two different electrolytic cells are constructed to electroplate two identical objects based on the half-reactions given in the table above. An object will be plated with a certain number of moles of <math alttext="A u" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in one cell, and in the other cell another object will be plated with the same number of moles of <math alttext="A g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the same amount of time. Which of the following mathematical relationships can be used to determine how much more current is needed to electroplate an object with <math alttext="A u" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than to electroplate it with <math alttext="A g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The difference in standard reduction potential of <math alttext="A u with a positive 3 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>is <math alttext="0.70 volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Three times more electrons are needed to reduce <math alttext="A u with a positive 3 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> than are needed to reduce <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is more negative for the reduction of <math alttext="A u with a positive 3 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> than for the reduction of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The molar-mass ratio of <math alttext="the fraction A u over A g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="the fraction 196.97 over 107.87" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>196.97</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>107.87</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Three times more electrons are needed to reduce <math alttext="A u with a positive 3 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Au</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> than are needed to reduce <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.B: Identify an appropriate theory, definition, or mathematical relationship to solve a problem.
